explanation:
The report is correct. The code calls strcmp(upg_header, WS_UPGRADE_VALUE) and strstr(con_header, "Upgrade") on pointers obtained from MHD_lookup_connection_value. That convenience function returns pos->value (without returning a length) but the underlying header storage in the library exposes pos->value_size and therefore may represent values with an explicit length rather than an ensured trailing NUL. Nothing in the shown code guarantees that pos->value is NUL-terminated, so using strcmp/strstr can make those functions read beyond the bounds of the value buffer while searching for a terminating NUL or a substring. That is exactly the situation Rule 21.17 forbids.

The checks for NULL pointers only prevent dereferencing NULL; they do not guarantee NUL-termination. To be MISRA-compliant, the code must use length-aware operations (for example obtain the value_size via MHD_lookup_connection_value_n and then compare the known constant length with value_size and use memcmp, or perform bounded substring search) or otherwise guarantee that the returned value buffers are NUL-terminated before passing them to string.h functions. The agent’s suggested fixes (use length-aware comparisons, or use the _n variant to get sizes and use memcmp/strncmp or a bounded search) are appropriate.
